questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with back pain and difficulty in bending forward. His X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dagger sign is a classical radiological feature of ankylosing spondylitis caused by ossification of the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments, producing a central dense line on the AP view of the spine.

  • Seen in advanced ankylosing spondylitis
  • Results from the calcification of midline spinal ligaments (interspinous/supraspinous)
  • Appears as a single vertical dense line on X-ray
  • Related sign: Trolley track sign is another feature of ankylosing spondylitis due to facet joint and ligamentous ossification forming parallel lines

Key Takeaway:

A dagger sign on spinal X-ray is due to ligament calcification in ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an extra-articular manifestation of Marie-Strumpell disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Marie-Strumpell disease is an eponym for Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS), a chronic inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy primarily affecting the axial skeleton.

Extra-articular manifestations include:

  • Eye: Anterior uveitis (most common)(Option A ruled out)
  • Cardiac: Aortic regurgitation, AV block(Option B ruled out)
  • Lungs: Apical pulmonary fibrosis(Option D ruled out)
  • Renal: IgA nephropathy, secondary amyloidosis
  • MSK: Achilles tendon enthesitis
  • CNS: Atlantoaxial subluxation

Dilated cardiomyopathy is not associated with AS.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with back pain and difficulty in bending forward for the last 3 years. His X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a classical "bamboo spine" appearance, which is diagnostic of ankylosing spondylosis.

  • Bamboo spine occurs due to syndesmophyte formation and ossification of ligaments (anterior longitudinal, interspinous).
  • This leads to loss of spinal flexibility and axial stiffness.
  • Morning stiffness and improvement with activity are hallmark clinical features.

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A): Primarily affects peripheral joints (MCP, PIP, wrist); the spine is rarely involved.

Osteoporosis (Option B): Causes vertebral compression fractures but not syndesmophytes or ligament ossification.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): Affects facet joints; does not cause bamboo spine or syndesmophyte formation.

Key Takeaway:

"Bamboo spine" on imaging is a radiological hallmark of ankylosing spondylosis, a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with polyarthralgia. O/E he has scaly lesions over the body and nail changes. Inflammation was maximum in the DIP of both hands. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scaly lesions and nail changes point towards psoriasis, and polyarthralgia is due to psoriatic arthropathy, which classically involves the DIP joint.

  • Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • DIP joint involvement is characteristic, unlike rheumatoid arthritis, which usually spares DIP joints.
  • Nail pitting and onycholysis are common features.
  • May also show "pencil-in-cup"deformity on X-ray in chronic cases.

Explanation of other options:

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (Option A): Usually causes symmetrical non-erosive arthritis and does not involve DIP joints or present with psoriatic plaques.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option C): Involves PIP, MCP, and wrist joints; DIP joints are typically spared.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): Can involve DIP joints (Heberden's nodes), but lacks inflammatory skin and nail findings.

Key Takeaway:

Psoriatic arthritis presents with DIP joint inflammation, nail pitting, and psoriatic skin lesions, distinguishing it from other inflammatory arthropathies.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with long-standing joint deformities. Examination shows severe digital shortening with telescoping of fingers. X-ray of the hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Opera glass hands are seen in psoriatic arthropathy.

  • Hand changes in psoriatic arthropathy are
    1. Sausage digits
    2. Opera glass hands (Main en Lorgnette)
    3. Arthritis Mutilans
    4. Pencil in cup deformity
    5. Gull-wing appearance

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A): Causes deformities like ulnar drift, boutonniere, and swan neck-does not lead to digital telescoping.

Systemic sclerosis (Option C): Causes skin tightening and acro-osteolysis but not opera glass hands.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): Causes Heberden/Bouchard nodes with joint space narrowing, not phalangeal resorption.

Key Takeaway:

Opera glass hand deformity is pathognomonic of arthritis mutilans, seen in severe psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with a known history of psoriasis presents with polyarthralgia. On examination, he has nail pitting, dactylitis of the right index finger, and pain at multiple small joints of the hand. Rheumatoid factor is negative. Which of the following criteria is used to diagnose his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The patient presents with classic features of psoriatic arthritis - skin psoriasis, nail changes, dactylitis, and negative rheumatoid factor. The CASPAR (Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis) is the most widely accepted diagnostic criterion for psoriatic arthropathy.

According to CASPAR criteria, a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis requires:

  • Inflammatory articular disease (joints, spine, or entheses) plus 3 or more points from the following:
    • Evidence of current psoriasis (2 points), past history or family history of psoriasis (1 point)
    • Psoriatic nail changes (1 point)
    • Negative rheumatoid factor (1 point)
    • Dactylitis (current or history) (1 point)
    • Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation (1 point)

Explanation of other options:

EULAR criteria (Option B): European League Against Rheumatism guidelines used for treatment monitoring, not diagnosis.

ARA criteria (Option C): American Rheumatism Association criteria used primarily for rheumatoid arthritis.

PSOR criteria (Option D): Not an established diagnostic set for psoriatic arthritis.

Key Takeaway:

The CASPAR criteria are the gold standard for diagnosing psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old child, who is a known case of haemophilia, presented with painful swelling of the right knee after a trivial fall. What should not be done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Joint aspiration is contraindicated in haemophilia as the bleeding will recur due to persistent clotting factor deficiency.

  • The child likely has hemarthrosis, a common manifestation of haemophilia after minor trauma.
  • Initial steps should include:
    • Imaging (X-ray) to rule out fracture(Option A ruled out)
    • Factor VIII assay to confirm deficiency(Option B ruled out)
    • Ice packs to reduce inflammation(Option C ruled out)
  • Aspiration is contraindicated unless absolutely necessary (e.g., for diagnostic dilemma or impending compartment syndrome).
  • Bleeding recurs post-aspiration due to ongoing clotting factor deficiency until factor replacement is given.

Key Takeaway:

Aspiration should be avoided in hemophilic hemarthrosis unless factor VIII replacement has been administered, due to the risk of recurrent bleeding.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a known history of recurrent joint bleeds presents with left lower abdominal fullness and difficulty in hip flexion. His labs show an isolated raised aPTT with a normal platelet count. What is the most likely muscle involved in this case of hemophilic pseudotumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The iliopsoas is the most common muscle involved in pseudotumor formation in haemophilia, presenting with a retroperitoneal mass and hip flexion difficulty.

  • Hemophilic pseudotumors are chronic expanding hematomas due to repeated bleeding into muscle in haemophiliacs.
  • Iliopsoas is the most commonly involved muscle due to its deep location and large vascular supply.
  • Patients often present with:
    • Lower abdominal or groin swelling
    • Hip flexion contracture or difficulty extending hip
    • Raised activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) as seen in haemophilia A or B
  • Other muscles occasionally involved:
    • Quadriceps (2nd most common)
    • Deltoid (most common in upper limb pseudotumors)

Explanation of other options:

Quadriceps (Option A): Commonly involved but less frequent than the iliopsoas.

Hamstrings (Option B): Rarely affected by pseudotumor formation.

Deltoid (Option D): Most common in the upper limb, not overall.

Key Takeaway:

In hemophilic patients, iliopsoas muscle hematoma should be suspected when there is abdominal swelling with hip dysfunction.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a painless deformity of the right foot and difficulty walking for 6 months. X-ray reveals dislocation at midtarsal joints and multiple intra-articular loose bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Charcot joint (neuropathic arthropathy) is a painless, destructive joint disease typically seen in diabetic patients with sensory loss.

  • Charcot joint is a form of neuropathic arthropathy most commonly seen in long-standing diabetics due to peripheral neuropathy.
  • The absence of pain despite joint deformity is a hallmark feature, attributed to loss of protective sensation.
  • Midtarsal joints are the most commonly affected joints in diabetic neuropathy.
  • The 6Ds on X-ray help identify the Charcot joint:
    • Distended joint
    • Disorganized articulation
    • Dislocation
    • Debris (loose intra-articular bodies)
    • Increased Density (subchondral sclerosis)

Destruction of articular surfaces

Explanation of other options:

Osteoarthritis (Option A): Causes pain and typically spares midtarsal joints.

Septic arthritis (Option C): Presents with acute pain, fever, and joint effusion-not typically painless.

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (Option D): A hereditary motor-sensory neuropathy; does not cause destructive joint changes seen in Charcot arthropathy.

Key Takeaway:

In a diabetic with painless foot deformity and destructive midfoot joint findings, Charcot joint should be the prime suspect.

questions.text: In which condition is the CROW brace used?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The CROW brace is designed to offload and immobilise the foot in patients with Charcot neuroarthropathy.

  • CROW stands for Charcot Restraint Orthotic Walker, used as a non-operative management strategy.
  • It is a custom-moulded, total-contact, below-knee brace that immobilises and offloads the foot and ankle.
  • Indicated in Charcot joints, especially in diabetic neuropathic arthropathy, where joint destruction and instability occur due to loss of protective sensation.
  • Provides both protection and mechanical stability during weight-bearing.

Explanation of other options:

Gout (Option A): Managed medically; braces are not routinely used.

Postoperative care (Option B): May require casts or standard walking boots-not a specific CROW brace.

Open fractures (Option C): Require surgical stabilisation and external fixation-not managed with a CROW brace.

Key Takeaway:

The CROW brace is specifically used for immobilising and supporting the foot in patients with Charcot neuroarthropathy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man developed severe pain in the great toe, one day after he attended his friend's bachelor's party. Serum Uric acid is 9. What is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
NSAIDs like indomethacin are the first-line treatment for acute gout attacks.

  • The patient has a classic presentation of acute gout, triggered by purine-rich food or alcohol (bachelor party context).
  • Serum uric acid >7 mg/dL confirms hyperuricemia.
  • Acute gout presents with sudden, severe monoarticular joint pain-most commonly the 1st MTP (podagra).
  • First-line treatment: NSAIDs (Indomethacin is preferred).
  • Uric acid-lowering drugs like allopurinol or febuxostat are contraindicated during acute attacks and should be started only after the attack subsides.

Explanation of other options:

Febuxostat (Option A): A xanthine oxidase inhibitor; used for chronic gout prevention, not during acute episodes.

Allopurinol (Option B): Another xanthine oxidase inhibitor; also contraindicated during acute gout.

Paracetamol (Option D): Provides mild analgesia but is ineffective in controlling gout-related inflammation.

Key Takeaway:

Acute gout should be treated with NSAIDs; urate-lowering therapy should begin only after the acute phase resolves.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man developed severe pain in his right knee, a day after he attended a marriage feast. O/E, there was effusion in the knee, but the X-ray was normal. Arthrocentesis was done, which showed negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals are pathognomonic of gout. These are crystals of monosodium urate (MSU)

  • In pseudogout, synovial fluid will show positively birefringent rhomboid crystals. These are crystals of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD)
  • Septic arthritis will show bacteria, elevated WBC count, elevated protein levels and reduced sugar levels in the synovial fluid.
  • In osteoarthritis synovial fluid will be normal.


Explanation of other options:

Pseudogout (Option A): Synovial fluid shows rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent CPPD crystals, not needle-shaped.

Septic arthritis (Option C): Characterised by purulent synovial fluid, bacterial growth, high WBCs, increased protein, and low sugar.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): Synovial fluid remains clear and non-inflammatory; crystals are absent.

Key Takeaway:

The presence of negatively birefringent needle-shaped MSU crystals confirms gout.

questions.text: 60 year 60-year-old lady developed severe pain in his right knee, a day after she attended a marriage feast. O/E, there was effusion in the knee, and X-ray showed a narrowed joint space. Arthrocentesis was done, which showed positively birefringent rhomboid crystals. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Pseudogout, there is deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals in the joint. These crystals are positively birefringent and rhomboid in shape.

  • Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals are pathognomonic of gout. These are crystals of monosodium urate (MSU)
  • Septic arthritis will show bacteria, elevated WBC count, elevated protein levels and reduced sugar levels in the synovial fluid.
  • In osteoarthritis synovial fluid will be normal.

Explanation of other options:

Gout (Option A): Characterised by monosodium urate crystals, which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent, not rhomboid or positively birefringent.

Septic arthritis (Option C): Presents with turbid synovial fluid containing bacteria, high white blood cells, elevated protein, and decreased glucose-no crystals seen.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): Synovial fluid is non-inflammatory with normal biochemistry and absent crystals.

Key Takeaway:

The presence of positively birefringent rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of pseudogout.

questions.text: Which of the following is an X-ray finding seen in hemophilic arthropathy of the knee joint?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Squaring of the patella is a characteristic radiological finding in hemophilic arthropathy, as per the Arnold-Hilgartner classification.

  • Hemophilic arthropathy results from repeated hemarthrosis leading to progressive joint damage.
  • X-ray findings evolve in stages:
    • Stage 1: Soft tissue swelling
    • Stage 2: Osteoporosis (earliest bony change)
    • Stage 3: Squaring of patella, widening of intercondylar notch, squaring of femoral condyles
    • Stage 4: Narrowing of joint space
    • Stage 5: Joint disorganisation
  • Osteophytes (Option B ruled out) are not a feature of hemophilic arthropathy-they are typical of osteoarthritis.
  • Inflammation (Option D ruled out) is a clinical feature, not a radiographic one.
  • X-ray findings in hemophilic arthropathy have been classified by the Arnold Hilgartner classification which is given below

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, a known case of CML on chemotherapy, presents with severe pain in his right knee. Aspiration of the knee joint showed negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals are pathognomonic of gout. These are crystals of monosodium urate (MSU).

  • When a patient is on chemotherapy, there is increased destruction of cells, which release purines, and uric acid is a byproduct of purine metabolism. Hence, there are elevated uric acid levels when someone is undergoing chemotherapy, which can cause gout.
  • In pseudogout, synovial fluid will show positively birefringent rhomboid crystals. These are crystals of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD)
  • Septic arthritis will show bacteria, elevated WBC count, elevated protein levels and reduced sugar levels in the synovial fluid.
  • In osteoarthritis synovial fluid will be normal.

Explanation of other options:

Pseudogout (Option A): CPPD crystals—rhomboid, positively birefringent, not needle-shaped.

Septic arthritis (Option C): Joint fluid shows pus cells, bacteria, ↓glucose, and no crystals are seen.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): Non-inflammatory synovial fluid; no crystals, no birefringence.

Key Takeaway:

Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals are diagnostic of gout due to monosodium urate deposition.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with chronic polyarthritis presents with neck pain and features of cervical myelopathy. Imaging reveals instability at the atlantoaxial joint. Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause atlantoaxial subluxation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Atlantoaxial subluxation is a serious complication affecting the upper cervical spine, particularly in inflammatory or congenital conditions.

  • Rheumatoid arthritis(Option A) is the most common cause due to chronic synovitis weakening the transverse ligament.
  • Ankylosing spondylitis(Option D) causes instability due to enthesitis and bone remodelling.
  • Odontoid dysgenesis (Option C) is a congenital anomaly that leads to defective odontoid development and instability.
  • Gout, although associated with tophaceous deposits in joints, does not commonly involve the upper cervical spine or cause atlantoaxial subluxation.

Key Takeaway:

Gout is not typically associated with atlantoaxial subluxation, unlike RA, odontoid anomalies, and spondyloarthropathies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with joint pain and stiffness with pigment deposition in joints. She has noticed that her urine darkens in colour some time after micturition. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alkaptonuria causes darkening of urine on standing and pigmentation of cartilage due to homogentisic acid accumulation.

  • Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase (HGD).
  • Leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in tissues, producing ochronosis.
  • Classical signs:
    • Urine darkens on standing due to oxidation of homogentisic acid.
    • Pigment deposits in joints, sclera, and ear cartilage.
    • Joint stiffness and early-onset arthritis, especially of the spine and large joints.
  • Other systemic manifestations may include cardiac valvular disease and renal stones.

Explanation of other options:

Phenylketonuria (Option A): Causes intellectual disability and a mousy odour of urine, not joint pigmentation.

Tyrosinemia (Option B): Presents with hepatic failure and renal involvement; no ochronosis.

Melanoma (Option D): Can cause dark pigment, but no relation to dark urine or joint ochronosis.

Key Takeaway:

Alkaptonuria presents with ochronotic pigmentation, early arthritis, and darkening of urine on standing.

questions.text: The given X-ray shows a well-defined periarticular erosion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The characteristic Martel's sign (overhanging margin with punched-out erosion) is diagnostic of chronic tophaceous gout.

  • Martel's sign (also called the "rat bite" or "overhanging edge" sign) is a classic radiologic feature of chronic gout.
  • Seen at the margins of tophi, where urate crystals erode bone, causing punched-out lesions with sclerotic, overhanging edges.
  • The most commonly involved joint is the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint.
  • Soft tissue swelling and joint space preservation are also commonly observed in early stages.

Explanation of other options:

Spondylolisthesis (Option A): Refers to anterior displacement of a vertebra, not joint erosion.

Scoliosis (Option B): A lateral curvature of the spine, unrelated to periarticular erosions.

Charcot's joint (Option D): Neuropathic arthropathy shows joint disorganisation, debris, and dislocation, not well-defined erosions.

Key Takeaway:

Martel's sign (overhanging margin) is pathognomonic for chronic gout.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with painless swelling and deformity of the right foot. Despite marked joint destruction on X-ray, he reports minimal discomfort. Examination reveals a warm, unstable foot with midfoot collapse and intact peripheral pulses. What is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diabetes mellitus is the most common cause of neuropathic (Charcot) joint, especially involving the foot.

  • Neuropathic (Charcot) arthropathy is a degenerative joint condition caused by sensory and proprioceptive loss.
  • Characterised by painless joint destruction, instability, deformity, and swelling.
  • The foot and ankle are most frequently affected.
  • Diabetes is the most common aetiology today due to peripheral neuropathy.

X-ray shows dislocation, fragmentation, and sclerosis (6 D's of Charcot joint).

Explanation of other options:

Syphilis (Option A): Previously common due to tabes dorsalis, but now rare.

Tuberculosis (Option B): Causes painful monoarthritis with systemic signs, not neuropathic joint.

IVDP (Option D): Causes radicular pain and neurological deficits, not joint disintegration.

Key Takeaway:

Charcot arthropathy, presenting with painless foot deformity and destruction, is most commonly caused by diabetes.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with swelling and pain in the right knee for 6 months. His x ray is shown here. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of multiple intra-articular loose bodies on X-ray is characteristic of synovial chondromatosis.

  • Synovial chondromatosis is a benign proliferative disorder of the synovium.
  • Cartilaginous metaplasia of synovium leads to the formation of multiple loose bodies.
  • Most commonly affects large joints-the knee being the most frequent.
  • Common in middle-aged men (30-50 years).
  • Symptoms include chronic pain, swelling, stiffness, and mechanical restriction.
  • Imaging shows multiple radio-opaque, similar-sized loose bodies in the joint space.
  • Management includes synovectomy and removal of loose bodies for symptomatic relief.

Explanation of other options:

X-ray artefacts (Option A): Artefacts do not produce such well-defined, joint-localised radio-opacities.

Synovial sarcoma (Option B): Malignant, aggressive lesion with soft tissue mass, not multiple loose bodies.

Chondrosarcoma (Option C): Bone tumour with cortical destruction and soft tissue extension-not confined to synovium.

Key Takeaway:

Multiple loose bodies in the knee joint of a middle-aged patient strongly suggest synovial chondromatosis.

choices.text: Adam's forward bending test - Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with chronic back pain and morning stiffness. A test is performed as shown in the image below to assess spinal mobility. Identify the test shown in the figure used to identify spine stiffness.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The modified Schober test is a clinical tool used to assess lumbar spine mobility in suspected ankylosing spondylitis.

  • A point is marked 10 cm above and 5 cm below the lumbosacral junction.
  • The patient is asked to bend forward maximally
  • Normally, the distance increases by at least 5 cm on forward bending.
  • A reduced increase indicates limited lumbar flexion, seen in ankylosing spondylitis.

Adam's forward bending test is performed by asking the patient to bend forward:

  • It helps screen for structural scoliosis by observing asymmetry in the rib cage or back prominence.
  • It is not used for assessing spinal stiffness.

Key Takeaway:

The modified Schober test is the preferred clinical tool for detecting reduced lumbar spine mobility in ankylosing spondylitis.
